item.title: Officials Pressed Schumer to Help Name Penn Station and Dulles Airport for Trump
item.description: Administration officials told the top Senate Democrat the president would release frozen funding for the Gateway project if the transportation hubs were renamed for him.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A construction site for the Gateway mass transit project in Manhattan on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Judge Says Trump Cannot Halt Funding for Gateway Tunnel Project
item.description: Nearly all of the work had stopped on Friday while negotiations continued in Washington and litigation played out in court.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan and Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A construction site for the Gateway mass transit project in Manhattan on Thursday.

item.title: Hegseth Says Defense Department Will Cut Ties With Harvard
item.description: Mr. Hegseth’s order appeared to target his alma mater, Harvard’s Kennedy School for public policy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

item.title: Trump Is Hosting Governors at the White House, but Only Republicans
item.description: The president’s decision to exclude Democratic governors from an annual meeting later this month breaks a longstanding tradition.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado has clashed with President Trump in recent months over Mr. Polis’s refusal to pardon Tina Peters, a former county clerk.

item.title: Trump Deletes Racist Video Portraying the Obamas as Apes
item.description: The video clip that President Trump posted in a late-night flurry of social media activity caused an unusually strong and public outcry from members of his own party.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Isabella Kwai and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Olympics Officials Signal Sanctions on Russia in Sports May End
item.description: In Milan this week, Olympics officials signaled a willingness to ease years of restrictions imposed on the country over its state-backed doping program and invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Athletes competing for the Russian Olympic Committee in the men’s ice hockey gold medal match at the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing. The team won a silver medal.

item.title: How Is Security Different at These Olympic Games?
item.description: Our sports correspondent Tariq Panja talks with Katrin Bennhold about the security at the Olympics in Italy, including the presence of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, who the U.S. says are there only in an advisory role.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja, Katrin Bennhold, Leila Medina and Laura Salaberry

item.title: JD Vance Is Booed at Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
item.description: Before the event, protesters marched in Milan in opposition to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, whose personnel are in Italy to advise local officials in securing the Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and Usha Vance at San Siro stadium for the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Milan on Friday.

item.title: Authorities Investigate a New Message in Nancy Guthrie Kidnapping Case
item.description: The F.BI. and local law enforcement gave no details about the note, which came on the sixth day of the search for Ms. Guthrie, the mother of the “Today” host Savannah Guthrie.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara/Associated Press
item.media:description: A sign of solidarity from neighbors at Nancy Guthrie’s home in Tucson.

item.title: Nancy Guthrie’s Disappearance Rekindles Kidnapping Fears
item.description: High-profile abductions, like those of Patty Hearst and J. Paul Getty III, have captured the nation’s attention, but experts say kidnappings by strangers are exceedingly rare.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: National Center for Missing and Exploited Children
item.media:credit: Jan Sonnenmair/Getty Images
item.media:description: The disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, the mother of the “Today” anchor Savannah Guthrie, is the latest case of its kind to capture the nation’s attention, reviving fears about kidnappings.

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Expedite Deportation of 5-Year-Old Liam Conejo Ramos
item.description: Liam was detained last month near Minneapolis during an immigration enforcement operation in which his father was also taken into custody by federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: U.S. Rep. Joaquin Castro, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Adrian Conejo Arias and his son, Liam Conejo Ramos, in San Antonio after being released from an immigration detention center in Dilley, Texas.

item.title: Cuban Deportees Who Were Transferred to Guantánamo Sent Back to U.S.
item.description: Dozens of men appear to be caught up in a political standoff between the Trump administration and Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Lauren Wood/The Natchez Democrat, via Associated Press
item.media:description: All but one of the men were being held on Friday at the Adams County Correctional Center in Natchez, Miss.

item.title: Bard College President Leon Botstein Was Close With Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: Bard College’s president, Leon Botstein, said his school needed cash. But a rare watch and a Caribbean visit show how his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein sometimes veered into the personal.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Botstein has been leading Bard College since 1975. He says his connections with Jeffrey Epstein were focused on raising money for the school.

item.title: Paul Weiss Partners Turned on Brad Karp After Learning Extent of His Epstein Ties
item.description: Mr. Karp resigned as chairman of the elite law firm after senior partners met to decide his future.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Rob Copeland, Maureen Farrell and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Karp’s problems began months ago when embarrassing revelations about his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein began to dribble out of the Justice Department’s files.

item.title: China Reverses Death Sentence for Canadian in a Small Win for Carney
item.description: The ruling by China’s highest court followed a recent meeting between China and Canada’s top leaders that led to a thaw in the two countries’ relations.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Intermediate Peoples' Court of Dalian, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Robert Lloyd Schellenberg in 2019 during his retrial on drug-trafficking charges in a court in Dalian, China.

item.title: Trump Says Talks With Iran Were Good, but There’s More Work to Do
item.description: President Trump said the negotiations would resume next week. Abbas Araghchi, the Iranian foreign minister, said the talks were off to a “good start.”
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: In Talks, Trump Won’t Allow Iran to Have Any Enriched Uranium
item.description: Can the two sides get past Iran’s claim that it has a “right” to enrich uranium?
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers at a uranium conversion facility in Isfahan, Iran, in 2005. Analysts say Iran’s position on enrichment reflects the country’s intense pride in a nuclear program that has become a symbol of Iranian independence.

item.title: In a Close Election, Voters Send a Sharp Anti-Trump Message
item.description: The Democratic primary to replace Gov. Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey in Congress is still too close to call. Much of the advertising focused on opposition to the president and his immigration policies.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Brian Fraser for The New York Times; Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Malinowski, left, and Analilia Mejia are in a tight Democratic primary race to fill Gov. Mikie Sherrill’s seat in Congress.

item.title: Why Are These Women Being Denied Visits With Loved Ones in NY Prisons?
item.description: Women hoping to visit their loved ones at New York prisons are being turned away after scanners pick up what they say are menstrual products. Some have had their visitation rights suspended.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Parnell
item.media:credit: Lauren Petracca for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Department of Corrections and Community Supervision suspended Samantha Works from visiting her husband, pictured, after prison officials accused her of carrying contraband into the Mohawk Correctional Facility.

item.title: N.Y.P.D. Sergeant Found Guilty in Death of Bronx Man He Threw Cooler At
item.description: Erik Duran was convicted of second-degree manslaughter, making him the first New York City police officer to be found guilty of killing a civilian while on duty in a decade.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Maria Cramer
item.category: Duran, Erik R (New York, NY, Police Officer)
item.media:credit: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergeant Erik Duran was convicted of second-degree manslaughter for the death of Erik Duprey on Friday.

item.title: Super Bowl Visitors Find San Francisco Better Than Its Apocalyptic Image
item.description: Problems with homelessness and open-air drug use have been widely broadcast, but many visitors this week said they found the city surprisingly pleasant.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Ferry Building is a popular spot for visitors walking along San Francisco Bay on the Embarcadero.

item.title: The Finance Industry Is a Grift. Let’s Start Treating It That Way.
item.description: Regulating the industry is useful. Shaming it is crucial.
item.dc:creator: Oren Cass

item.title: We Didn’t Ask for This Internet
item.description: Cory Doctorow and Tim Wu explain why the internet failed to live up to its early promise.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein and Annie Galvin
item.category: Enshittification: Why Everything Suddenly Got Worse and What To Do About It (Book)
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Stocks Rebound After Volatile Week as Dow Hits Record High
item.description: The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 50,000 points for the first time, as old line stocks come back into vogue.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: The Dow Jones industrial average on Friday had its best day since May as it closed above 50,000 points for the first time.

item.title: Saalumarada Thimmakka Dies; Planted and Nurtured Thousands of Trees
item.description: Believed to be 113, she spent decades building an environmental legacy in India, inspired by her grief at being unable to conceive children.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.

item.title: In the Grip of Gangs, Haiti Faces a Government Leadership Vacuum
item.description: The tenure of a presidential council that has been running Haiti expires on Saturday. It’s unclear what will come next.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre
item.media:credit: Clarens Siffroy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A view from inside an armored police vehicle showing cars burned by armed gangs and used as a barricade on a deserted street Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Body of Nathan Smith, Lil Jon’s Son, Found in Georgia Pond, Police Say
item.description: Nathan Smith, whose stage name is DJ Young Slade, was reported missing on Tuesday after running out of his home in a community north of Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Pencils of Promise
item.media:description: The rapper Lil Jon, left, with his son, Nathan Smith, in 2018. The police said the body of Mr. Smith was recovered from a pond in Georgia on Friday.
